messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:26): hmm. i have opera mobile 11 on android 2.3.3, HTC Gracia which is ARM6. webm.html5.org says it doesn't support WebM
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:37): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: what does http://webm.html5.org/debug/ say?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:37): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I may have introduced a bug when I tried to blacklist Opera Mobile on Symbian
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:46): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it says Android 2.2, (empty), (empty)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:47): shows a video element but doesn't play anything
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:47): i thought i had upgraded to 2.3.3
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:47): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: oh so Opera Mobile now reveals the Android version. interesting
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:48): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: could you paste the entire UA string, please?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:50): sent by email
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:52): it seems i still have android 2.2, but no new updates are available

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:53): othermaciej, I agree that sometimes reviewing code properly takes more time than writing it, but normally it takes much less time.  In particular, well-written patches should include enough comments, documentation, and explanation that they're reasonably easy to review, and if they don't, the reviewer can ask for them.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:53): In most cases.  You'll still always have some hard-to-review patches, in the end.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:53): (you probably have a lot more experience reviewing patches than I do, though, and maybe you review them more thoroughly)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:54): I do think that in commit-then-review, reviewers have a lot less power than in review-then-commit.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:54): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: what does the ADR number mean in the UA string?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:54): Is there any software project that uses CtR?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:54): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, I'm going to spec everything execCommand()-related eventually, but there's loads to do.  The only thing I'm really working on speccing right now is the algorithm for applying inline markup commands.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:55): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, MediaWiki, for one.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:55): It's probably a bad idea, and most of us seem to be in favor of switching to RtC.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:55): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Well that seems like a bad idea

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:55): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, I should say, I'm going to do it if time allows.  I still have a few months left, though, so it's likely that I'll be able to finish it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:56): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, yes, it is, which is why a lot of us want to change it.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, if you count projects that have a status of "commit access" but no formal review process as CtR, then I suspect it's more popular overall than RtC.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:00): Although big, prominent, well-run projects tend to use RtC.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:02): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I refined the Android advice that webm.html5.org gives
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:02): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I think "we don't have review" is a bit different to CtR
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:02): Maybe, yeah.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:02): it still sucks that Firefox is tied to CPU and Opera to the Android version
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (17:02): You'll still usually have some sort of informal review in such cases, though.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:02): I wonder how many Android users know what CPU their device has :-(
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:03): e.g. html5lib doesn't really have review. Except that I have never committed a patch from a non-core-contributer without reviewing it first
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:03): For single person projects the concept of review doesn't even make sense
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:04): I'd love to know if the default browser on Android 2.3.3 supports WebM and if Opera Mobile 11 on Android >= 2.3 but < 2.3.3 supports WebM
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:10): for additional Android fragmentation FAIL, HTC doesn't list the Android version or the CPU instruction set in its product specs
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:11): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I tried to update my android device but it requires a SIM card‚Ä¶
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:12): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: so the device works without a SIM in general but doesn't update without a SIM?
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:12): I'm using it on wifi all the time in the office for testing but never as a phone
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:12): is this some user-hostile mechanism that allows updates to be blocked by operator?
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:12): might be
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:13): because otherwise, people with hostile operators could just take out the SIM and upgrade over wifi
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:13): the mobile business is so sad
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:14): as someone reminded recently, home ISP was bad 10 years ago
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:14): even Apple, the supposed savior of users from operator hostility, reportedly requires partner operators to impose data transfer caps in order sell iPads
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:14): that's so crazily bizarre.
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:15): like you could only use the ISP modem, you couldn't use more than one machine behind the modem, etc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:15): maybe they want their product offering to suck everywhere as much as it sucks in the U.S. or something
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:15): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: in France? it wasn't like that in Finland in 1995
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:16): they weren't enforcing the "one machine" rule a lot, but it was in the contract
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:17): and the plans were limited in time, only 10/20/50 hours a month
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (17:19): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: It was the same way in the US back then :(
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:20): hopefully one ISP was aggressive enough to change a lot of those rules and we now have one of the cheapest internet access
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (17:20): and this ISP (Iliad/Free) should launch mobile plans next year, hopefully changing the market in the same way
